DOCNAME: CASE OF VLASOV AND BENYASH v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 2 of Protocol No. 4 - Freedom of movement-{general} (Article 2 para. 2 of Protocol No. 4 - Freedom to leave a country);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed (Article 41 - Pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction);Non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
JUDGES: Branko Lubarda;Dmitry Dedov;Helen Keller;Helena Jäderblom;Johannes Silvis;Luis López Guerra;Pere Pastor Vilanova
TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The first applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON applied to ORG for a travel passport which would allow him to go abroad .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE convicted him of smuggling and sentenced him as follows :
“ ... the penalty in the form of CARDINAL PERSON imprisonment is not to be enforced and is to be considered conditional with a DATE period .
To require Mr PERSON to report twice a DATE during DATE to the authority in charge of execution of conditional sentences , and to inform [ that authority ] of any change of residence ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE his application for a travel passport was refused by reference to the fact that he had been given a suspended threeyear sentence whose period of suspension had not yet expired .
CARDINAL . The applicant Mr PERSON applied for judicial review of the refusal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the refusal as lawful , finding as follows :

“ The argument by Mr PERSON to the effect that ORG judgment of DATE contained an exhaustive list of restrictions during the probation period which did not include a restriction on leaving GPE and which was not , in the claimant ’s view , subject to expansive interpretation by ORG officials , does not contradict section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Entry and Exit Procedures Act which provides for a restriction on the right to leave for abroad in cases of both actual custodial and suspended sentences . A person who is given a suspended sentence is a convicted offender serving a sentence , and may be relieved from punishment only after the period of suspension has expired . Mr PERSON ’s period of suspension expires on DATE and after its expiry Mr PERSON ’s criminal conviction will be spent in accordance with LAW . Until that time Mr PERSON is an offender serving a sentence , which is a ground for restricting his right to leave for abroad . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected an appeal against ORG judgment . It held :

“ The arguments that Mr PERSON was subjected to restrictions that go beyond those imposed by his conviction and that he was compelled to serve the sentence within GPE , whereas he needed to take care of his business interests and perform his duties abroad , are not grounds for setting aside the correct judgment [ of the first - instance court ] . ”
CARDINAL . The second applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE convicted PERSON of extortion and sentenced him to CARDINAL GPE imprisonment , suspended for DATE . He was released in the courtroom . On DATE ORG upheld the conviction on appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused Mr PERSON ’s application for a travel passport , noting that he had been arrested on CARDINAL DATE and that , according to the available information , the criminal proceedings against him were still pending .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant Mr PERSON applied for judicial review of the refusal .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE upheld the refusal as lawful :
“ ... for the time being the conviction of DATE is not yet spent , Mr PERSON is a convicted offender , and , accordingly , the refusal [ of travel documents ] does not violate his rights ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the appeal , endorsing the reasoning of ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused him leave to appeal to the cassation instance .
